questions.text: Which is the branch of the anterior internodal tract that connects the right and left atria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The branch of the anterior internodal tract that connects the right and left atria is the Bachmann bundle.

Conductive system of the heart:

  • In the human heart, the SA node is the pacemaker of the heart. Impulses from the SA node are spread through the heart via various tracts.
  • There are three bundles in the atrial fibres that connect the SA node to the AV node. They contain Purkinje fibre (Option D ruled out)
  • The anterior, middle, and posterior tracts connect the SA node to the AV node.
    • The anterior tract, also called the Bachmann bundle, connects the SA node to the left atrium. (Option C)
    • The middle bundle of the tract is known as the Wenckebach tract. (Option A ruled out)
    • The posterior tract is called the tract of Thorel. (Option B ruled out)
  • Conduction through these bundles is more rapid than in cardiac myocytes.

choices.text: Purkinje fibres are larger than nodal fibres
Purkinje fibres have more mitochondria than nodal fibres
Purkinje fibres have slower conductivity than nodal fibres

questions.text: Purkinje fibres in the conductive system of the heart differ from the SA/AV node by which of the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the conductive system of the heart, Purkinje fibres are larger than nodal fibres.

  • Characteristics of Purkinje fibres are
    • Large cells
    • Fewer mitochondria and striations (Option B ruled out)
    • Faster conduction (Option C ruled out)
  • The conduction system is composed of modified cardiac muscle that has fewer striations and indistinct boundaries.
  • The Purkinje fibre system spreads the impulse through all cardiac muscle cells.
  • Characteristic of Nodal fibres are
    • Small in size
    • Sparse striations
    • Slower conduction (Due to their higher internal resistance)

choices.text: Due to a delay in conduction, the atria contract before the ventricles
Lack of inward sodium current in depolarisation contributes to slow conduction
AV nodal delay can be shortened by stimulation of sympathetic nerves

questions.text: True about AV nodal delay is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The SA node initiates depolarisation, which then spreads to the atria and subsequently to the AV node.
  • If the conduction through the AV node is faster, the delay of depolarisation in the AV node is
  • In this case, atrial and ventricular depolarisation overlap. It reduces the end diastolic volume.
  • But the conduction in the AV node is slower. It causes ventricular depolarisation after atrial depolarisation. (Option A is true)
  • Causes of delay are
    • INa+ in the depolarisation (phase 0) of the action potential is seen in cardiac muscle, but in the pacemaker it is absent, leading to slow depolarisation. (Option B is true)
    • The nodal delay is shortened by stimulation of the sympathetic nerves to the heart and lengthened by stimulation of the vagi. (Option C is true)

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Depolarisation of the ventricular muscle starts from the right side of the interventricular septum
The depolarisation wave spreads from the septum directly to the base of the ventricle
It proceeds from epicardial to endocardial surface

questions.text: Which of the following is a fact about Ventricular depolarisation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The following is a direction of spread of depolarisation in the ventricles.

  • Ventricular muscle depolarisation starts from the left side of the interventricular septum. (Option A ruled out)
  • Then it moves first to the right side across the mid portion of the interventricular septum.
  • Afterwards, it spreads down to the apex of the heart. (Option B ruled out)
  • It returns along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardium to the epicardial surface. (Option C ruled out)
  • And lastly, the postero-basal portion of the left ventricle, the pulmonary conus, and the uppermost portion of the septum depolarise.
  • The time taken for the wave of depolarisation from the left side of the septum to all parts of the ventricles by Purkinje fibres is 0.08 to 0.1 seconds.

questions.text: Following is a diagram of the pacemaker potential. Identify the cause of the potential change marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

After hyperpolarisation, Na+ and K+channels called h channels (also known as funny or f channels) open.

  • The basis of automaticity is the funny current (If), also known as leaky funny current.
  • This current is not due to a stimulus but is a continuous leak of cations.
  • The influx of T-type calcium and slow sodium is responsible for the funny current.
  • As Ih increases, the membrane begins to slowly depolarise; this constitutes the first part of the pacemaker (prepotential) phase.

The pacemaker potential is generated by pacemaker tissues, such as the SA node and AV node.

  • There are two types of voltage-gated Ca²+ channels in the heart:
    • T-type (transient) calcium channels: open early, help complete the pacemaker potential. (Option B ruled out)
    • L-type (long-lasting) calcium channels: open at threshold, responsible for the upstroke of the action potential (Phase 0) (Option A ruled out)
  • Repolarisation from the peak of the impulse is caused by K+ efflux through voltage-gated K+ channels, which increases membrane potassium conductance. (Option C ruled out)
  • Once repolarisation is complete, the membrane potential declines to a negative value, triggering reopening of Ih channels, and the cycle repeats.

Key Takeaway:

After Na+ and K+ channels open up following hyperpolarisation, it refers to the h channel. The current through this channel is h current. They are also called funny (f) channels.

questions.text: Unlike ventricular myocytes, the SA node and AV node action potentials do not exhibit a sharp, rapid depolarising spike preceding the plateau phase. What is the most likely reason for the absence of this feature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The action potentials in the SA and AV nodes are largely due to Ca2+ influx, with no contribution from Na+ influx.
  • Na+ channels are very fast to respond, and a rapid rush of Na+ ions from outside to inside due to higher gradients will suddenly raise the depolarisation in the cardiac muscle.
  • Ca++ channel current slowly rises compared to Na+ channels. So, no sudden spike is observed.
  • Leaky channels in the 1stpart of the potential are responsible for the automatic rise to the threshold.
  • L-type Ca++ channels are responsible for depolarisation.

Explanation for other options:

Presence of K⁺ channels (Option B): While K⁺ channels are involved in repolarisation (Phase 3) of the action potential, they do not affect the sharpness of depolarisation. Their presence does not explain the absence of a rapid upstroke.

High resting potential (Option C): Nodal cells have a less negative resting membrane potential (about -60 mV), which keeps Na⁺ channels in an inactivated state. However, it is the absence or inactivation of Na⁺ channels, not just the higher resting potential alone, that explains the slow depolarisation.

All of the above (Option D): Not all listed options equally contribute to the phenomenon. The primary and most specific reason is the absence of functional Na⁺ channels.

Key Takeaway:

The action potentials in the SA and AV nodes are largely due to Ca2+ influx, with no contribution from Na+ influx.

choices.text: Increase in K+ conductance in the nodal tissue
Reduced depolarizing effect of h current

questions.text: A patient admitted to the emergency department was mistakenly administered a cholinergic drug. Shortly thereafter, the patient developed bradycardia. What is the most likely mechanism responsible for the bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Well known effect of cholinergic drugs on the heart is to produce
  • Vagal stimulation is also known to produce bradycardia in a subject.
  • In both conditions, an increase in acetylcholine increases the K+ conductance in the nodal tissue. (Option B is correct)
  • Due to this effect, there is hyperpolarisation of the membrane of the nodal tissue. It reduces the slope of the (Option A is correct)
  • This action is mediated by M2 muscarinic receptors, which, via the βγ subunit of a G protein, open a special set of K+ channels. The resulting K+ currents reduce the depolarising effect of the h current. (Option C is correct)
  • It also slows down the opening of Ca++ channels. It causes a decrease in firing rate in the nodal tissue.

choices.text: It increases the Na+- K+ ATPase activity
It decreases the AV nodal conduction velocity
It increases the ventricular filling pressure

questions.text: A 69-year-old patient was prescribed digoxin to enhance cardiac contractility. Which of the following statements regarding digoxin is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Digoxin is a digitalis group of drugs. It is derived from a common foxglove plant known as Digitalis purpurea.

It alters the electrical activity in the heart, as it decreases the AV nodal conduction velocity, thus delaying AV transmission to the ventricles. (Option B)

Explanation for other options:

The principal effect of digoxin is that it inhibits Na-K ATPase activity, leading to a greater amount of Ca++ release. (Option A ruled out) It will increase the force of contraction in the heart muscle.

Due to the above effect, cardiac output improves, also improving left ventricular emptying and decreasing the ventricular filling pressure. (Option C ruled out).

It is useful in heart failure. Digitalis reduces the number of impulses transmitted through the AV node and thus provides effective rate control in atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

Key Takeaway:

  • The principal effect of digoxin is that it inhibits Na-K ATPase activity, leading to a greater amount of Ca++ release. It will increase the force of contraction in the heart muscle.
  • It decreases the AV nodal conduction velocity, thus delaying AV transmission to the ventricles.

questions.text: The phase 1 in cardiac muscle action potential is
questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient went to the emergency department with crushing chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, he has tachypnea. An ECG is performed, which shows significant ST-segment changes in lead V2 (intense negative injury potential changes). Which of the following areas of the heart shows ischemic changes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The intense injury potential in chest lead V2 having strong negative injury potential during the T-P interval is found, which means that the chest electrode over the front of the heart is in an area of strongly negative potential which means that the current of injury is emanating from the anterior wall of the ventricles, which diagnoses this condition as an anterior wall infarction.

Explanation for other options:

Old myocardial infarction (Option D): It typically shows deep Q waves on ECG due to necrotic tissue. It does not present with ST-segment changes or injury patterns, which are signs of acute events.

questions.text: Following is a normal ECG pattern in augmented unipolar leads. Identify the lead.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given ECG image is of Lead aVR (Augmented Vector Right), which is an augmented unipolar limb lead that records electrical activity from the right upper limb.

  • In a normal ECG, aVR typically shows a dominantly negative QRS complex because the heart's depolarisation vector is moving away from the right arm.
  • The negative deflection helps differentiate it from other augmented limb leads like aVL and aVF.

Explanation for other options:

aVL limb lead (Option A): Usually shows a small positive or biphasic QRS, not a deeply negative complex.

aVF limb lead (Option C): Typically shows a positive deflection as it views from the foot, aligned with the downward cardiac vector.

V4 chest lead (Option D): A precordial lead showing a positive R wave, located at the midclavicular line in the 5th intercostal space. Not an augmented limb lead.

Key Takeaway:

In lead V1, exploring electrodes are placed in the left 4th intercostal space, right to the sternum. Here, the average current direction is towards the left foot, as the current flows opposite to the exploring electrode, showing a negative deflection.

questions.text: Following is an electrogram of cardiac tissue. It is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In His bundle electrogram, A deflection when the AV node is activated, an H spike during transmission through the His bundle, and a V deflection during ventricular depolarisation.

  • A wave represents conduction time from the SA nodeto the AV node.
  • AH interval represents the AV nodal conduction time.
  • The HV interval represents conduction in the bundle of His and the bundle branches.
  • In normal cardiac muscle, ECG P, QRS complex, and T waves are seen.
  • In the pacemaker potential, which is the potential in the SA node. Resting potential is -55mV to -60mV, and waves of depolarisation and repolarisation are seen.

Explanation for other options:

SA node (Option A): The SA node has slow depolarisation due to Ca²-mediated action potentials, with no distinct sharp spike.

Ventricular (Option B): Ventricular tissue has a broad, high-amplitude QRS-like complex on electrogram, not a sharp His signal.

Key Takeaway:

In His bundle electrogram, A deflection when the AV node isactivated, an H spike during transmission through the His bundle, and a V deflection during ventricular depolarisation.

choices.text: Atrial depolarisation and conduction through the AV node
Conduction from the SA node to the ventricular depolarisation

questions.text: Give the significance of the following interval shown.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The following marked area is thePR interval, which is marked from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex, which shows Atrial depolarisation and conduction through the AV node.
  • P wavedenotes atrial
  • The QRS complexshows ventricular
  • Conduction from the SA node to the ventricular depolarisation is from the beginning of the P wave to the end of the QRS complex.

Explanation for other options:

Atrial depolarisation (Option A): This is represented solely by the P wave, not the entire PR interval

Conduction from the SA node to ventricular depolarisation (Option C): This corresponds to the interval from the start of the P wave to the end of the QRS complex.

Ventricular depolarisation (Option D): This is represented by the QRS complex alone, not the PR interval.

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents to the primary care physician with palpitations and dizziness. His ECG shows irregularly irregular QRS complexes without discernible P waves. Which of the following arrhythmias is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In atrial fibrillation, the atrial muscle fibres depolarise one by one in portions. So, no discernible P waves are seen.

Explanation for other options:

Ventricular tachycardia (Option A): The ECG of ventricular tachycardia has the appearance of a series of ventricular premature beats occurring one after another, without any normal beats interspersed.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option B): Ventricular fibrillation results from cardiac impulses that have gone berserk within the ventricular muscle mass, stimulating first one portion of the ventricular muscle, then another portion, then another, and eventually feeding back onto itself to re-excite the same ventricular muscle over and over, never stopping.

Atrial flutter (Option D): Atrial flutter causes a rapid rate of contraction of the atria, usually between 200 and 350 beats/min. However, because one side of the atria is contracting while the other side is relaxing.

choices.text: Mobitz type I second degree AV block
Mobitz type II second degree AV block

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient was admitted to the emergency dept due to syncope. ECG reveals a pattern in which some P waves are conducted to the ventricles while others are blocked. The PR interval progressively lengthens until a P wave is completely blocked. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is Mobitz type Iheart block, where

  • The PR interval progressively increases with each beat
  • Eventually, a P wave fails to conduct to the ventricles (dropped QRS)
  • The cycle then repeats
  • Often benign, but can cause dizziness or syncope

Explanation for other options:

Key Takeaway:

In Mobitz type I heart block, there are repeated sequences of beats in which the PR interval lengthens progressively until a ventricular beat is dropped.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents for a routine check-up. During the examination, the physician observes a pulse that varies with respiration. A cardiotachometer recording is obtained: the left panel shows a normal pattern, while the right panel shows the recording during deep breathing. What is the most likely physiological phenomenon represented?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sinus arrhythmia is a variation in the heart's normal sinus rhythm where the time between heartbeats (P-P interval) fluctuates, specifically by more than 120 milliseconds, commonly observed in young individuals.

  • During inspiration, there is typically a slight increase in heart rate, while during expiration, the heart rate decreases slightly.
  • This is due to changes in vagal tone with respiration on the SA node.

Explanation for other options:

Sinus bradycardia (Option A): It is a slow heart rate originating from the sinus node, specifically less than 60 beats per minute. It's a type of bradyarrhythmia where the heart's electrical impulses originate from the sinoatrial (SA) node but at a slower than normal rate. This slower rate can be due to issues with the SA node itself (intrinsic) or external factors (extrinsic).

Sinus tachycardia (Option C): Sinus tachycardia is a regular cardiac rhythm with a heart rate exceeding 100 beats per minute in adults, originating from the sinoatrial node. It is a common response to various physiological stressors like exercise, stress, or illness. While it can be a normal response, persistent or inappropriate sinus tachycardia can be a sign of underlying medical conditions.

Premature atrial contractions (PACs) (Option D): Premature atrial contractions (PACs) are contractions of the atria that are triggered by the atrial myocardium but have not originated from the sinoatrial node (SA node). PACs are also commonly referred to as atrial premature complexes (APCs), premature supraventricular complexes, premature supraventricular beats, and premature atrial beats. This phenomenon can be caused by an assortment of medical diseases, structural abnormalities, pharmaceuticals, and non-regulated compounds.

choices.text: The negative electrode is applied to the left arm
The negative electrode is applied to the left leg
The positive electrode is applied to the left arm

questions.text: True about lead III in bipolar limb leads is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the lead III in bipolar limb leads, the Negative electrode is applied to the left arm.

  • Standard limb leads are bipolar limb leads I, II, and
  • Bipolar limb leads record the potential difference between two limbs.
  • Current flows only in the body fluids; the records obtained are those that would be obtained if the electrodes were at the points of attachment of the limbs at any point in the limb.
  • Lead l: Negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm, and positive terminal to the left arm.
  • Lead II: The negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm, and the positive terminal to the left leg.
  • Lead III: The negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the left arm, and the positive terminal to the left leg.

questions.text: Following is a mean electrical axis in a male of 43 years of age. Please interpret this graph for the disorder.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The causes of left axis deviation are left ventricular hypertrophy and left bundle branch block.

  • The normal direction of the mean QRS vector is generally -30° to +110°.
  • Usually, the mean electrical axis is 60 degrees towards the foot.
  • If the calculated axis falls left to -30°, it is identified as left axis deviation.
  • If the calculated axis in the vector cardiogram falls right to 110°, then it is considered a right axis deviation.
  • The causes of right axis deviation are right ventricular hypertrophy, right bundle branch block.

Explanation for other options:

Left posterior hemiblock (LPHB) (Option A): LPHB results in right axis deviation due to delayed activation of the posterior fascicle. The ECG shows an axis of> +110°, which contradicts the axis shown here.

Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) (Option B): RVH causes the QRS axis to shift rightward, often > +110°, due to dominant right ventricular mass. The current axis in the ECG is leftward, not rightward.

Right bundle branch block (RBBB) (Option D): RBBB does not typically cause axis deviation unless combined with other pathology. It leads to widened QRS complexes and an rSR' pattern in V1. Axis usually remains within normal range, so a leftward shift does not align with RBBB alone.

questions.text: Following is a diagram of His bundle electrogram. The cause of the A deflection in the electrogram is due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The A deflection seen in the His bundle electrogram (HBE) represents atrial activation reaching the AV node. It reflects the electrical activity as it passes from the atria to the AV node.

The His bundle electrogram is a valuable diagnostic tool, especially for evaluating conduction disorders like heart block. It captures three main components:

  • A wave: Atrial depolarisation reaching the AV node
  • H spike: The H spike (not A wave) is produced during conduction through the His bundle. (Option B ruled out)
  • V deflection: The V deflection corresponds to ventricular activation. (Option C ruled out)

Associated Intervals:

  • PA interval: From atrial depolarisation (on surface ECG) to A wave on HBE -reflects conduction from SA node to AV node.
  • AH interval: From A wave to H spike - reflects AV node conduction time
  • HV interval: From H spike to ventricular activity (QRS onset)- reflects His-Purkinje conduction time

questions.text: Following is an ECG of a 39-year-old male appearing for fitness for a new insurance policy. Calculate the heart rate per minute from the ECG below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ECG can be used to calculate the heart rate.
  • We use either the R-R interval or the P-P interval to calculate heart rate.
  • It can be calculated by dividing 1500 by the number of small squares in the R-R interval or P-P interval, or by dividing 300 by the number of large squares in the R-R interval or P-P interval.

Small Square Method

Heart Rate = 1500 / (Number of small squares between R-R)

  • In this ECG:
    1500 / 19 small squares = ~78 bpm

Large Square Method

Heart Rate = 300 / (Number of large squares between R-R)

  • In this ECG:
    300 / 3.6 large squares = ~83 bpm

Both calculations give a heart rate that falls between 75 and 85 bpm.

Key Takeaway:

Heart rate can be calculated by dividing 1500 by the number of small squares in the R-R interval or P-P interval, or by dividing 300 by the number of large squares in the R-R interval or P-P interval.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male came for a routine health check-up. On cardiovascular examination, he is found to have sinus arrhythmia. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sinus arrhythmia refers to the normal variation in heart rate with the respiratory cycle, most commonly seen in young healthy individuals. This is primarily mediated by fluctuations in vagal (parasympathetic) tone.

  • It accelerates during inspiration, and it decelerates during the expiration process, especially during deep inspiration.
  • During inspiration, impulses from the stretch receptors via the vagi inhibit the cardioinhibitory area in the medulla oblongata.
  • The tonic vagal discharge that keeps the heart rate slow decreases, and the heart rate rises.
  • Sympathetic fluctuations usually do not occur during deep inspiration.

Explanation for other options:

Fluctuation in sympathetic output (Option A): While sympathetic activity does influence heart rate, sinus arrhythmia is predominantly vagally mediated, not due to sympathetic tone variation.

Heart failure (Option C): Heart failure may cause various arrhythmias, but sinus arrhythmia is a benign, normal finding and is not caused by heart failure.

Emotional excitement (Option D): Emotional stress can lead to increased sympathetic drive and sinus tachycardia, not sinus arrhythmia.

Key Takeaway: Sinus arrhythmia is a normal phenomenon occurring due to fluctuations in the parasympathetic output.

questions.text: Idioventricular rhythm is seen in what type of heart block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Idioventricular rhythm is seen in complete heart block

  • Idioventricular rhythm refers to a slow ventricular rhythm (usually 20-40 beats per minute) that arises independently from the ventricles, rather than being conducted from the atria.
  • It occurs when the normal pacemakers (SA node and AV node) fail to conduct impulses to the ventricles, and thus the ventricles initiate their own rhythm via an ectopic ventricular focus.

This is typically seen in complete heart block (third-degree AV block), where:

  • There is no conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles.
  • The atria and ventricles beat independently (AV dissociation).
  • The ventricles rely on an escape rhythm from a pacemaker site within the ventricular conduction system - an idioventricular rhythm.

Depending on the site of the block:

  • If the block is at or near the AV node, the junctional escape rhythm (40–60 bpm) may be seen.
  • If the block is infranodal (below the AV node), a slower idioventricular rhythm (20–40 bpm) typically occurs.

QRS complexes are conducted at their own rate and are independent of the P waves

Explanation for other options:

First-degree heart block (Option A): When conduction between the atria and ventricles is slowed but not completely interrupted, incomplete heart block is present. In the form called first-degree heart block.

Second-degree Mobitz type I block (Option B): In Mobitz type I heart block, there are repeated sequences of beats in which the PR interval lengthens progressively until a ventricular beat is dropped.

Second-degree Mobitz type II (Option D): While some P waves are blocked, others are conducted normally, so the ventricles still receive intermittent impulses from the atria.

questions.text: An electronic pacemaker is implanted in a 57-year-old male. It helps in generating the normal heart rate. Which of the following is/are indication/s of pacemaker implantation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sick sinus syndromeis due to dysfunction in the sinus node. This disorder may include tachycardia, bradycardia or alternate tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome. (Option A)
  • Trifascicular block refers to the presence of conduction delays or blockages in all three fascicles of the heart's ventricular conduction system,the right bundle branch and the two divisions of the left bundle branch. (Option B)
  • Neurogenic or vasovagal syncope is a transient syncope due to a sudden drop in blood pressure and heart rate. (Option C)
  • When there is marked bradycardia in patients with sick sinus syndrome, also when there is sinus node dysfunction (trifascicular block) pacemaker is very useful. A pacemaker is useful in patients with severe neurogenic syncope, in whom carotid sinus stimulation produces pauses of more than 3 s between heartbeats.

Indications of pacemaker implantation.

  • Sick sinus syndrome
  • Trifascicular block
  • Acquired Atrioventricular(AV) block
  • Chronic bifascicular block
  • After the acute phase of myocardial infarction
  • Neurocardiogenic syncope and hypersensitive carotid sinus syndrome
  • Post-cardiac transplantation
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Pacing to detect and terminate tachycardia
  • Cardiac resynchronisation therapy in patients with severe systolic heart failure
  • Patients with congenital heart disease

choices.text: Presence of a Bundle of Kent

questions.text: The following diagram illustrates the process of depolarisation in cardiac tissue. What do the last two panels in the diagram most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bundle of Kent is an accessory conduction pathway that bypasses the AV node and connects the atria directly to the ventricles. It is commonly associated with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which can lead to reentrant tachyarrhythmias due to premature excitation of the ventricles.
  • A conduction defect that allows a wave of excitation to propagate continuously within a closed circuit.
  • Likewise, if a transient block is present on one side of a portion of the conducting system, the impulse can go down the other side. When the block wears off, the impulse may go back in a retrograde direction in the previously blocked side, back to the origin and then descend again, establishing a circus movement.
  • Circus movements can also become established in the node as well as atrial or ventricular muscle fibre

Explanation for other options:

Sinus Arrhythmia (Option A): Sinus arrhythmia is a normal physiological phenomenon. It reflects respiratory variation in vagal tone: heart rate increases with inspiration and decreases with expiration. It does not involve abnormal conduction pathways or reentry circuits.

Complete Heart Block (Third-degree AV Block) (Option C): In this condition, no impulses are conducted from the atria to the ventricles. Atria and ventricles beat independently, often with an idioventricular rhythm. The diagram does not reflect AV dissociation, but rather an aberrant conduction pathway.

questions.text: A 41-year-old patient underwent clinical evaluation, including electrocardiography (ECG) and vectorcardiography. The mean electrical axis was found to be 50 degrees. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this axis deviation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The normal direction of the mean QRS vector is generally −0° to +110°. Usually, the mean electrical axis is 60 degrees towards the foot.
  • If the calculated axis falls left to -30°, it is identified asleft axis deviation.
  • If the calculated axis in the vector cardiogram falls right to 110°, then it is considered aright axis deviation.
  • Here, the mean electrical axis is found to be deviated toward the left, producing left axis deviation.
  • It is a sign ofleft ventricular hypertrophy. (Option C)
  • Aortic stenosisand systemic hypertension increase the work to be done by the left ventricles. (Options A and B)
  • In all cases, there is enlargement of the left ventricle.

choices.text: Pressure applied over the eyeball produces the oculocardiac reflex
It stimulates the sympathetic supply to the heart
Causes an increase in heart rate

questions.text: True about the oculocardiac reflex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When the pressure is applied to the eyeball, it causes reflex vagal discharge.

Explanation for other options:

  • Stimulation of the vagus nerve produces bradycardia by decreasing the rate of discharge from the SA node. (Option C ruled out)
  • It converts tachycardia and sometimes converts atrial flutter to normal sinus rhythm.
  • For information: Atropine can reduce the effect of the oculocardiac reflex.
  • Sympathetic supply to the heart is via the T1-T5 spinal cord segments. Rather than influencing the heart rate from SA nodes, the major effect is on the heart muscles. (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaway: When the pressure is applied to the eyeball, it causes reflex vagal discharge.

Stimulation of the vagus nerve produces bradycardia by decreasing the rate of discharge from the SA node.

questions.text: Following is an ECG of a 61-year-old male. Identify the abnormality of the ECG.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Premature beatsthat originate in an ectopic ventricular focus usually have bizarrely shaped, prolonged QRS complexes.
  • Following depolarisation from an ectopic focus, the impulse produces a premature beat. It is followed by a compensatory pause. After that, again, it starts the normal rhythm.

Explanation for other options:

Ventricular tachycardia (Option A): In Ventricular tachycardia, the ventricular rhythm is normal, but the rate is more than 100 per minute.

Torsades de pointes (Option B): It is a form of ventricular tachycardia in which the QRS morphology varies.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option C): In ventricular fibrillation, the ventricular muscle fibres contract irregularly and ineffectively because of the very rapid discharge of multiple ventricular ectopic foci or a circus movement with the heart rate.

Key Takeaway:

Premature beats that originate in an ectopic ventricular focus usually have bizarrely shaped, prolonged QRS complexes.

questions.text: Arrhythmia refers to an abnormality in the heart's rhythm. Effective and timely treatment is essential. One therapeutic approach involves modulation or blockade of specific ion channels. Prolongation of refractoriness in cardiac tissue is primarily achieved through the modulation of which ion channel?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amiodarone is a drug that prolongs the refractoriness of K+ channels. Thus depresses the ectopic activity and reduces the discrepancy between normal and reentry path. Sotalol and dofetilide have similar actions.

Explanation for other options:

Quinidine (Option A): It can slow down INa with minimal prolongation of refractoriness.

Nifedipine and diltiazem (Option C and D): These are calcium channel blocker drugs. They block L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels that can slow SA pacemaker and AV conduction.

For information: drugs that block β-adrenergic receptors, thus reducing the activation of ICaL, are propranolol, metoprolol.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 39-year-old male presents for a routine check-up. On ECG recording, prominent Q waves are observed. What is the most likely clinical significance of this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In old myocardial infarction, the dead muscle and scar tissue become electrically silent. The infarcted area is therefore negative relative to the normal myocardium during systole, and it fails to contribute its share of positivity to the electrocardiographic complexes. The size of the Q wave increases in some cases in the ECG.

Observation of Q waves in leads II, III and aVF shows OLD inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Explanation for other options:

Acute myocardial infarction (Option A): The hallmark of acute myocardial infarction is ST-segment elevation. There is slow depolarisation due to the current of injury. The injured area remains positive compared to the healthy tissue. The resultant current flow is a depression of the TQ segment of the ECG, which is noted as ST segment elevation.

Stable Angina pectoris (Option B): In stable angina during ischemia, the affected subendocardial region becomes electrically less negative compared to the surrounding healthy tissue, leading to a reduction in its resting membrane potential. In stable angina, the ECG is usually normal at rest, though ST depression may be seen during exertion. Q waves are not characteristic.

Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) (Option B): LVH shows tall R waves in left-sided leads (I, aVL, V5, V6) and deep S waves in right-sided leads. Q waves are not a feature of LVH.

questions.text: Following ECG changes are noted in a 25-year-old patient. It shows a tall T wave in the ECG. It is most probably due to which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Here in ECG, PR and QRS intervals are normal, but there is a tall T wave.
  • Hyperkalemia as a manifestation of altered repolarisation in ECG tall T waves is noted at around plasma K+ levels of around 7.5meq/litre.
  • Potassium levels more than 8.5 mEq/L cause prolongation of QRS complexes.

ECG changes associated with hyperkalemia:

  1. Peaked T waves: This is the earliest and most characteristic finding in hyperkalemia. The T waves become tall and pointed, often resembling a "tented" appearance.
  2. Prolonged PR interval: As potassium levels rise, the PR interval, which represents the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel from the atria to the ventricles, can become longer.
  3. Widened QRS complex: In severe hyperkalemia, the QRS complex, which represents the electrical activity of the ventricles, can widen significantly. This can lead to a "sine wave" pattern, which is a dangerous rhythm that can progress to ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest.
  4. Loss of P waves: In advanced hyperkalemia, the P waves, which represent the electrical activity of the atria, may become small and eventually disappear altogether.
  5. Bradycardia: Hyperkalemia can also cause bradycardia, a slow heart rate.

Explanation for other options:

Hyponatremia (Option A): A fall in the plasma level of Na+ may be associated with low-voltage electrocardiographic complexes.

Hypocalcemia (Option B): Hypocalcemia causes prolonged ST segment and QT interval. Hypercalcemia usually does not affect the heart.

Phenothiazine administration (Option D): Administering phenothiazine or tricyclic antidepressant causes the same effect as hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old average individual was doing exercise. His heart rate increased to 185 beats per minute. He started having chest pain and ischemic symptoms. What could be the most suitable cause for this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At high heart rates (>180 bpm), the duration of diastole shortens much more than systole. This disproportionately affects:

  • Ventricular diastole, which is the phase when:
    • Coronary blood flow occurs (especially during the relaxation of the left ventricle).
    • The heart muscle receives oxygenated blood via the coronary arteries.

A reduced diastolic period → inadequate coronary perfusion → myocardial ischaemia and chest pain, especially during high oxygen demand (like exercise).

The normal duration of each phase of the cardiac cycle at a heart rate of 70 per minute.

As the heart rate is increased to around 185 beats per minute, the duration of systole becomes 0.18 seconds, and the duration of ventricular diastole becomes nearly 0.18 seconds from 0.5 seconds. (Option A ruled out)

  • It is during diastole that the heart muscle rests, and coronary blood flow to the subendocardial portions of the left ventricle can only occur during diastole.
  • So, reduced blood supply leads to ischemic symptoms in this case.
  • Atrial systole and atrial diastole do not have a significant role in cardiac activity. (Options B and D ruled out)
